posts.name: Chris_Elston
posts.cooked: How can one install a Minion Motor or X44 onto an older Versa Planetary gear box? I believe there aren't any suitable input options for a Versa Planetary, but I’d appreciate any advice or insights.

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: Someone set this up with the kraken x66 so this might be a helpful thread Kraken x60 to versa planetary

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked: I got a couple of these guys 3D metal printed (SLM 316 Stainless Steel) a while back. The fit seems good planning to test durability in the next day or two. Works for standard x60s as well as x44s and Minions. Full-size Kraken x60s can use the standard Vex CIM Adapter for mounting assuming you cut the shaft down. For x44s or Minions it’s fairly straightforward to 3D print a comparable mounting adapter. Versaplanetaries load ratings state that for a Falcon 500 ratios higher than 30:1 should not be used. Performance wise x44s are roughly equivalent to a Falcon 500 Minions similar too but a full-size x60 is quite a bit more powerful and likely shouldn’t be used for most applications.

posts.name: Chris_Elston
posts.cooked: I know some people who use powered metal presses, I wonder if they could press those yet. That is pretty good though. I didn’t know you could 3D print Stainless steel!

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked: I didn’t know you could 3D print Stainless! Me either; I kinda stumbled across it.Apparently, you can also 3D print Titanium, Aluminum, and Tool Steel through the SLM process. I picked stainless steel because it was the cheapest option at the time.
Out of curiosity, how much did something like this run you for cost? Quantity? Turn around time.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked: They’re under $7 each plus shipping costs. The lead time is approximately two weeks, plus shipping time (which can range from 3 to 5 business days when I order through DHL). On my first purchase, I bought 5 units. After receiving them, I modified the product slightly to strengthen areas that appeared too thin. When I placed an order for 15 more recently, I expected delivery within a few days; however, there was a one-week delay due to the Chinese New Year. Interestingly, the total quantity I ordered did not seem to have a significant impact on the overall price.

posts.name: Stewart Riley
posts.cooked: It’s actually easier to adapt them than it was for Falcons. All you need is the CIM adaptor and the old 8mm input for the shaft. SplineXS shafts are 8mm OD, so the old inputs work just fine on them. We’ve actually done this and had no problems.

posts.name: Chris_Elston
posts.cooked: We have BOTH.
This is very cool. Would you be willing to share the model?

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked: Sure

link_counts.title: VersaPlanetary Reinforced SplineXS Adapter.stl - Google Drive

posts.name: Mark Wasserman
posts.cooked: We created a 3D plastic prototype from our CAD release. Despite applying significant torque with an X60 dynamometer, we were unable to dismantle it. While expertise or "tribal knowledge" may be required to properly secure it, if you're interested, I’m willing to share further details.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Not fast swerve, but good swerve driven quickly

posts.name: seg9585
posts.cooked: We tested carbon fiber-polycarb filament with 100% infill and found no damage. Although we didn’t use it on the robot due to design changes, we would have been satisfied with the results. A similar situation occurred with the Kraken-MAXPlanetary adapter, which was unavailable for extended periods.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked: They were ordered via CraftCloud. The timing aligns with my experience when purchasing stainless steel prints there. Pricing is highly competitive.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked: planning to test durability in the next day or two. Did you ever end up testing the durability? Never had time to do actual destructive testing on them, but for what it’s worth, we used three of them on our robot this year (including on at least one mechanism that saw a lot of high-energy direction changes) and never had any issues with them. We plan to keep using them going forward. They’re under $7/ea plus shipping Woah very competitive. Where did you order from? These ones we got from pcbway though we’ve also ordered similar parts from jlc in the past. At the time pcbway offered the faster turnaround and better deal

link_counts.title: Request CNC machining quotes | Online Manufacturing - PCBWay

posts.name: Elliot S
posts.cooked: These ones we got from PCBWay though we’ve also ordered similar parts from JLC in the past. At the time PCBWay offered the faster turnaround and better deal although I know that takes a lot of post processing work. It would be cool if SendCutSend or fabworks had Metal 3D printing

The Kraken-MAXPlanetary adapter was out of stock for months, similar to an experience shared by others. This year, we couldn’t obtain Kraken adapters either, so we used Falcons instead along with their respective adapters. While we would have preferred to stick with all Kraken adapters, we made do with what we could.
